Generation I.Red: A Pok é mon that was resurrected from a fossil found in what was once the ocean floor eons ago.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: A Pok é mon that was resurrected from a fossil found in what was once the ocean floor eons ago.
Generation I.Yellow: A Pok é mon that was recovered from a fossil. It uses the eyes on its back while hiding on the sea floor.
Generation I.Stadium: A Pokémon that was resurrected from a fossil found in an ancient seabed. Unable to right itself if it is flipped over.

Generation II.Gold: On rare occasions, some have been found as fossils which they became while hiding on the ocean floor.
Generation II.Silver: This Pok é mon lived in ancient times. On rare occasions, it has been discovered as a living fossil.
Generation II.Crystal: Three hundred million years ago, it hid on the sea floor. It also has eyes on its back that glow.
Generation II.Stadium 2: On rare occasions, some have been found as fossils which they became while hiding on the ocean floor. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) This Pok é mon lived in ancient times. On rare occasions, it has been discovered as a living fossil. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Kabuto is a Pok é mon that has been regenerated from a fossil. However, in extremely rare cases, living examples have been discovered. The Pok é mon has not changed at all for 300 million years.
Generation III.Sapphire: Kabuto is a Pok é mon that has been regenerated from a fossil. However, in extremely rare cases, living examples have been discovered. The Pok é mon has not changed at all for 300 million years.
Generation III.Emerald: It is a Pok é mon that has been regenerated from a fossil. However, in rare cases, living examples have been discovered. Kabuto have not changed for 300 million years.
Generation III.FireRed: This Pok é mon was regenerated from the fossil of an ancient creature. It protects itself with a hard shell.
Generation III.LeafGreen: A Pok é mon that was regenerated from a fossil found in what was once the ocean floor long ago.

Generation IV.Diamond: It is thought to have inhabited beaches 300 million years ago. It is protected by a stiff shell.
Generation IV.Pearl: It is thought to have inhabited beaches 300 million years ago. It is protected by a stiff shell.

Generation VI.X: It is thought to have inhabited beaches 300 million years ago. It is protected by a stiff shell.
Generation VI.Y: This Pokémon was regenerated from the fossil of an ancient creature. It protects itself with a hard shell.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Kabuto is a Pokémon that has been regenerated from a fossil. However, in extremely rare cases, living examples have been discovered. The Pokémon has not changed at all for 300 million years.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Kabuto is a Pokémon that has been regenerated from a fossil. However, in extremely rare cases, living examples have been discovered. The Pokémon has not changed at all for 300 million years.

Generation VII.Ultra Sun: This Pokémon thrived 300 million years ago. It's said that living specimens can still be seen in a certain region—a rare sight.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: This Pokémon became extinct everywhere, except in a few areas. It protects itself with its hard shell.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: A Pokémon that was recovered from a fossil. It used the eyes on its back while hiding on the seafloor.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: A Pokémon that was recovered from a fossil. It used the eyes on its back while hiding on the seafloor.

Generation VIII.Sword: This species is almost entirely extinct. Kabuto molt every three days, making their shells harder and harder.
Generation VIII.Shield: While some say this species has gone extinct, Kabuto sightings are apparently fairly common in some places.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It is thought to have inhabited beaches 300 million years ago. It is protected by a sturdy shell.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It is thought to have inhabited beaches 300 million years ago. It is protected by a sturdy shell.
